translated: The Monastic Code of the Elders
The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on training rules
1. The training rule on looking up

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, the Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū tahaṁ tahaṁ olokentā antaraghare gacchanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū tahaṃ tahaṃ olokentāḥ antara ghare gacchanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were walking in inhabited areas, looking all around.

analyzed: okkhitta cakkhu antaraghare gamissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will walk in inhabited areas without looking all around,’ this is how you should train.”

analyzed: okkhitta cakkhunā antara ghare gantabbam yuga mattam pekkhantena
translated: One should walk in inhabited areas without looking all around, but looking only a plow’s length ahead.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca tahaṁ tahaṁ olokento antaraghare gacchati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.🔽Anāpatti—
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca tahaṃ tahaṃ olokentaḥ antaraghare gacchati āpatti dukkaṭassa  anāpatti
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, walks in an inhabited area looking all around, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
There is no offense if it is unintentional,
if he is not thinking,🔽if he does not know,🔽if he is sick,🔽if there is a danger,
if he is the first offender.🔽The seventh training rule is finished.
